Brooke |alma_mater = [[University of Virginia]] }} '''George Felix Allen''' (born March 8, 1952) is a former [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Virginia]], and the son of former [[National Football League|NFL]] head coach [[George Allen (football)|George Allen]]. Allen served Virginia in the state legislature, as the [[List of Governors of Virginia|67th]] [[Governor of Virginia|Governor]], and in both bodies of the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]], winning election to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] in [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 2000|2000]]. Allen's re-election in the [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 2006|2006]] race seemed likely until he was accused of using a racist epithet when referring to a staffer of his opponent, [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Jim Webb]]. Allen lost the election to Webb by fewer than 10,000 votes.{{cite web|last=Mulkern |first=Anne C. |url=http://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/06/02/02greenwire-george-allen-returns-tries-to-counter-democrat-78713.html |title=George Allen returns, tries to counter Democrats on climate |publisher=The New York Times |date=June 2, 2009 |accessdate=2012-09-30}} Allen now serves on the [[Rancho del Cielo|Reagan Ranch]] Board of Governors of [[Young America's Foundation]] where he is a Reagan Ranch Presidential Scholar. Allen was the Republican candidate in the [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 2012|2012 election]] for the Senate, which he lost to [[Tim Kaine]]. ==Early life, education, and early law career (1952-1982)== Allen was born in [[Whittier, California|Whittier]], California. Allen's father, [[George Allen (American football coach)|George Herbert Allen]], was a legendary [[National Football League|NFL]] coach who was inducted into the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] in 2002.{{cite news |url=http://www.profootballhof.com/hof/member.jsp?player_id=14 |title=George Allen|publisher=[[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Football Hall of Fame]] |year=2006 }} During the 2006 senatorial campaign it was revealed that Allen's mother, Henrietta [[Lumbroso]], was born to [[Sephardic Jewish]] parents in [[Tunisia]].{{cite news|title=New 'N Word' Woe For George Allen|publisher=CBS News|date=September 26, 2006|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/09/26/politics/main2039589.shtml|accessdate=August 30, 2007}} He has a younger sister, Jennifer, an author and correspondent for [[NFL Network]], and two brothers, including [[Bruce Allen (American football)|Bruce Allen]], the current general manager of the [[Washington Redskins]] and former general manager of the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]]. He and his family lived there until 1957. They moved to the suburbs of Chicago after George Sr. got a job with the [[Chicago Bears]]. Then, the family moved back to Southern California ([[Palos Verdes]]) in 1966 after Allen's father was named head coach of the [[Los Angeles Rams]].{{cite news |url=http://football.about.com/od/arenafootball/l/bl_georgeallen.htm |title=George Allen: Pro Football Hall of Fame Head Coach |publisher=[[About.com]] |year=2006 }} Allen graduated in 1970 from [[Palos Verdes High School]], where he was a member of the [[falconry]] club and the car club. He was also [[quarterback]] of the varsity [[football team]]. Allen attended the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], for a year. His father had in the meantime taken over the head coaching duties with the Washington Redskins in 1970 and the younger Allen transferred to the [[University of Virginia]], in 1971, where he received a B.A. degree with distinction in history in 1974. He was class president in his fourth year at UVA. After graduating, Allen completed a [[Juris Doctor]] degree from the [[University of Virginia School of Law]] in 1977. In 1976 he was the chairman of the "Young Virginians for [[Ronald Reagan]]". ==Virginia House of Delegates (1982-1991)== ===Elections=== Allen's first race for the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] was in 1979, two years after he graduated from law school. He placed third in a field of four candidates. Allen states that he lost because he wasn't himself and was listening to the advice of his campaign manager who suggested he wear [[brogues|wingtips]] instead of his usual [[cowboy boots]]. He ran again in 1983 with the cowboy boots and won the election, defeating incumbent Democrat James B. Murray, whose 24th district was eliminated after redistricting.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WT&p_theme=wt&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB0EF5B8FC5840C&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Coach Allen would love this fight |publisher=The Washington Times |date=September 27, 1991 |accessdate=2012-09-30}}{{cite web|url=http://dela.state.va.us/dela/MemBios.nsf/735bd5cd47938ad585256c23006d3f8a/e4ef4e14c8ea301085256b35005fcf1a?OpenDocument |title=Welcome to the Virginia House of Delegates |publisher=Dela.state.va.us |date=1920-07-04 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} Peter T. Way, then named Paul Harris, succeeded Allen.{{cite news |url=http://www.americanprowler.org/dsp_article.asp?art_id=10100|title=The Jeffersonian |publisher=[[American Spectator]] |date=July 18, 2006 |first=Daniel |last=Holeman}} The seat he held was the same one held by [[Thomas Jefferson]].{{cite web|title=Governor George Allen|url=http://www.yaf.org/GeorgeAllen.aspx|work=Young America’s Foundation|accessdate=May 22, 2011}} ===Tenure=== He was a delegate from 1983 to 1991. He lived in [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]] and represented parts of [[Albemarle County, Virginia|Albemarle County]] and [[Nelson County, Virginia|Nelson County]]. Allen was a strong advocate for the [[Capital punishment in Virginia|death penalty]], and actively supported expanding it in Virginia. For several years in a row, Allen introduced a bill that would add murder in commission of an attempted robbery to the list. Each year, the bill died in the House Courts of Justice Committee. Allen would continue to collect newspaper clippings for his file and followed every murder in the state.{{cite web|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1989-01-16/news/8901160050_1_robbery-attempt-death-penalty-law-store-clerk |title=Delegate Renews Fight To Expand Death Penalty |publisher=Daily Press |date=1989-01-16 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} Allen supported a statewide referendum on whether or not to create a [[Virginia Lottery|state lottery system]].{{cite news|last=Gersh|first=R. D.|title=Lottery bill heading for vote by delegates|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kg8QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PIwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6743,388459&dq=george+allen+virginia+delegate&hl=en|newspaper=The Free Lance-Star|date=February 3, 1983}} In 1986, he proposed a referendum that would allow assets of illegal drug dealers to go to law enforcement.{{cite news|title=Editorial: Digging into dealers' pockets, not taxpayers'|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BWUQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I4wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6411,81186&dq=george+allen+charlottesville&hl=en|newspaper=The Free Lance-Star|date=November 1, 1990}} ===Committee assignments=== *House Courts of Justice Committee *House General Laws Committee *House Health Welfare and Institutions Committee *House Militia and Police Committee{{cite web|url=http://dela.state.va.us/dela/MemBios.nsf/735bd5cd47938ad585256c23006d3f8a/e33d6a44637bab9885256b35005fcf80?OpenDocument |title=Welcome to the Virginia House of Delegates |publisher=Dela.state.va.us |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}} *House Mining and Mineral Resources Committee{{cite web|url=http://dela.state.va.us/dela/MemBios.nsf/735bd5cd47938ad585256c23006d3f8a/1335ea49b1a7507785256b35005fcf2a?OpenDocument |title=Welcome to the Virginia House of Delegates |publisher=Dela.state.va.us |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}} ===Caucus memberships=== *Regional Party Whip *House Legislative Caucus{{cite web|url=http://dela.state.va.us/dela/MemBios.nsf/735bd5cd47938ad585256c23006d3f8a/3f1c078881f1e3df85256b35005fcf82?OpenDocument |title=Welcome to the Virginia House of Delegates |publisher=Dela.state.va.us |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}} ==U.S. House of Representatives (1991-1993)== ===Elections=== ;1991 Incumbent Republican U.S. Congressman [[D. French Slaughter, Jr.]], of [[Virginia's 7th congressional district]], decided to resign because of a series of strokes. Allen faced Slaughter's cousin, Kay Slaughter, who was also a Charlottesville City Councilman. Allen defeated her 64%-36%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=141643 |title=VA District 7 Special Race - Nov 05, 1991 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}}{{cite web |authorlink=Jake Tapper |first=Jake |last=Tapper |url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/11/17/robb/print.html |title=Dead senator running? | work=[[Salon magazine]] |date=November 17, 1999}} ;1992/redistricting In the 1990s round of [[United States congressional apportionment|redistricting]], Allen's district, which stretched from the fringes of the [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] suburbs to [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]] and included much of the [[Shenandoah Valley]], was eliminated, even though Virginia gained a congressional seat as a result of the [[United States Census, 1990|1990 Census]]. While Republicans claim the principal factor in redistricting were partisanship of the [[Democratic party (United States)|Democratic]] controlled [[Virginia General Assembly]], available new [[Geographic information system|GIS technology]] were forecasting likely election behavior of some hypothetical districts. The [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] had a mandate to create a black-majority district in accordance with the [[Voting Rights Act]]. Allen's district was eliminated as a result.{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=iTdFWR4Y-y8C&pg=PA323&lpg=PA323&dq=virginia+(1991+OR+1990)+redistricting&source=bl&ots=lssd-WnK7P&sig=HYGfhTmJaJI9vRErOSQ6_L6OmVY&hl=en&ei=yk1xTLSuAcTflged3KzLDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CDMQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=virginia%20(1991%20OR%201990)%20redistricting&f=false |title=Race and Redistricting in the 1990s |page=315 & seq. |editor1-link=Bernard Grofman |editor1-first=Bernard |editor1-last=Grofman |authorlink= |first=Winnett W. |last=Hagens |chapter=The Virginia Redistricting Experience, 1991–1997 |series=Agathon series on representation |publisher=Algora Publishing |location=New York |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-87586-262-0 |edition=softcover |accessdate=August 22, 2010}} While his home in [[Earlysville, Virginia|Earlysville]] was placed in the [[Virginia's 5th congressional district|5th District]] of [[Lewis F. Payne, Jr.]], most of his district was placed in the newly redrawn [[Virginia's 10th congressional district]], represented by fellow Republican [[Frank Wolf]]. Allen moved to [[Mount Vernon, Virginia|Mount Vernon]] and prepared to challenge Wolf in a primary. [[Republican Party of Virginia|state Republican leaders]] had let it be known that he could not expect any support for his planned run for governor in 1993 if he made such a challenge. Allen decided not to run in either the 5th, nor the 10th. After Democrat U.S. Congressman [[James Olin]] of the [[Virginia's 6th congressional district]] decided to retire, there was speculation Allen could run there. However, he decided not to move his family and run in the 6th district either.{{cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFF4D4B2FAB410&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=The Virginian-Pilot Archives |publisher=Nl.newsbank.com |date=1991-12-20 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} ===Committee assignments=== *[[U.S. House Committee on Small Business]]{{cite web|title=Revolving Door: George Allen Employment Summary|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/revolving/rev_summary.php?id=70304|publisher=OpenSecrets|accessdate=30 September 2012}} *[[U.S. House Committee on Science]] *[[U.S. House Committee on the Judiciary]] ==Virginia Governor (1994-1998)== [[Image:George Allen visiting USS George Washington, July 22, 1996.JPEG|thumb|right|Governor Allen visiting the [[USS George Washington (CVN-73)|USS ''George Washington'']] in July 1996.]] In November 1993, Allen was elected the 67th [[Governor of Virginia]], serving from 1994 to 1998. His opponent in the 1993 election, Attorney General [[Mary Sue Terry]], had an early 29-point lead in public opinion polls{{cite news |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00610F73F550C708CDDA80994DB494D81&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fD%2fDemocratic%20Party |title=The 1993 Elections: Virginia; Conservative Republican Wins Easily |work=New York Times |author=B. Drummond Ayres Jr |date=November 3, 1993}} and a million-dollar fundraising advantage.{{cite web |url=http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/valeg/php/candidates.php?eid=1993RVAG |title=The Virginia Elections and State Elected Officials Database Project, 1776–2005 |publisher=University of Virginia Library |accessdate=November 9, 2006}} However, Allen struck a hot button with voters across party and racial lines with his campaign proposal to abolish parole. This response to a surge of crime in the state connected with voters, in contrast to Terry's proposal to increase [[gun control]] as a remedy.{{cite web |url=http://www.heritage.org/Research/PoliticalPhilosophy/HL628a.cfm |title=Remarks of Governor George Allen to the Heritage Foundation |publisher=The Heritage Foundation |author=George Allen |date=December 9, 1998 |accessdate=November 9, 2006}}{{Verify source|date=July 2007}} Allen overcame the deficit and won with 58.3% of the vote, the largest margin (+17.4 points) since [[Albertis S. Harrison Jr.]] defeated [[H. Clyde Pearson]] with a margin of +27.7 points in 1961.[http://fisher.lib.virginia.edu/collections/stats/valeg/php/election.php The Virginia Elections and State Elected Officials Database Project, 1776–2005]{{cite web|url=http://ourcampaigns.com/ContainerHistory.html?ContainerID=286 |title=Governor of Virginia |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2012-09-30}} Allen could not run for re-election because Virginia's constitution does not allow a governor to succeed himself; {{As of|2012|lc=on}} Virginia is the only state that has such a provision.{{cite news |url=http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/VA-news/VA-Pilot/issues/1996/vp960516/05160010.htm |title=One Price of a One-Term Governor High Turnover|publisher=[[The Virginian-Pilot]] |page=A14 |date=May 16, 1996 |accessdate=October 4, 2006 }} ===Welfare reform=== During his 1993 campaign for Governor, Allen vowed to reform Virginia's welfare system, stating that "Our obligation as a society is to provide a hand up to those in need, rather than a handout ...Welfare is not to be a permanent status for anyone in life."Harris, John F. [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-960732.html "Allen Urges VA Welfare Restrictions; Plan Would Require Job, Two-Year Cutoff"], Washington Post", August 17, 1993 At the time welfare caseloads climbed 36 percent from 1988 while one out of twelve Virginians were receiving food stamps.Piper, Laura, [http://rjolpi.richmond.edu/archive/Volume_I_Issue_2.pdf "Virginia As A Model for Other State Welfare Plans,"] Welfare Reform: A New Deal for the 1990s. Retrieved January 24, 2011, Vol 1. Spring 1997 Number 2 In March 1995, after an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote of support, Allen signed his welfare reform bill propelling Virginia ahead of the national welfare reform effort,Taylor, Leslie, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_sction=search&p_maxdocs=200&p "Welfare Reform Arrives"], "The Roanoke Time", March 16, 1994Cain, Andrew, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WT&p_theme=wt&p_actio "Last-minute Deal Brings Virginia Welfare Reform"], "The Washington Times,", p. A01 Retrieved June 30, 2010 Among the key provisions outlined in the bill, the Virginia Initiative for Employment Not Welfare (VIEW) limited Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF) benefits for welfare recipients to two years while recipients are required to work within ninety days of receiving benefits.Cain, Andrew, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WT&p_theme=wt&p_actio "Last-minute Deal Brings Virginia Welfare Reform"], "The Washington times,", p. A01 Retrieved June 30, 2010 Following VIEW's implementation, welfare caseloads decreased 33 percent, from 73,926 families in March 1995 to 49,609 families in July 1997.Report of the Department of Social Services. [http://leg2.state.va.us/dls/h&sdocs.nsf/fc86c2b17a1cf388852570f9006f1299/9c300efba45f74e28525656e0058dc0a/$FILE/HD22_1998.pdf "Making Welfare Work: Virginia's Transformation From Dependency to Opportunity"] In areas where VIEW existed for twelve months, 74 percent were employed versus only 31 percent nationally,.{{cite web|url=http://www.urban.org/uploadedPDF/900980_welfarereform.pdf#search=%22%20a%20parent%20working%2020%20hours%20a%20week%20at%20the%20federal%20minimum%20wage%20receives%20TANF%20benefits%20in%20the%20majority%20of%20states.%22 |title="A Decade of Welfare Reform: Facts and Figures," The Urban Institute |date= |accessdate=2012-09-30}} According to the Virginia Department of Health and Human Resource's 1996 annual report, VIEW saved taxpayers 24 million dollar in its first year of existence; with an addition to federal welfare money, the savings total over the following two years comes to just over $70 million (December 19, 1995) "Savings Estimated On Welfare Reform," Richmond Times Dispatch. pg. A14.) The Allen Administration's welfare reform law also addressed concerns over single-parent recipients of welfare requiring mothers to name the child's father and provide three additional pieces of information to help locate the non-custodial parent or face loss of all TANF benefits.LaDonna Pavetti; Nancy Wemmerus [http://www.mathematica-mpr.com/PDFs/vafull.pdf. February 1999] Since 1995, Virginia has achieved a 98.5 percent rate of paternity identification, the highest in the country.Metcalf, Robert C., [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action "Welfare Moms and Kids Benefit From Reform"], The Virginian-Pilot", August 27, 1997 By removing the incentive to break up families, the Allen welfare reform allowed two parent households the same time to receive benefits as single parents. Because this law reversed the incentive of being a single parent TANF cases represented by two parent households increased by over 180 percent.Report of the Department of Social Services [http://leg2.state.va.us/dls/h&sdocs.nsf/fc86c2b17a1cf388852570f9006f1299/9c300efba45f74e28525656e0058dc0a/$FILE/HD22_1998.pdf "Making Welfare Work: Virginia's Transformation From Dependency to Opportunity", June 30, 2010 ] ===Truth-in-sentencing=== In November 1993, Allen’s campaign promise to abolish parole for violent criminals helped drive him to a landslide victory after trailing from a 33 percent point deficit in the polls to Democrat Mary Sue Terry,Gemma Jr., Peter B., [http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/4191231.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS&date=Oct+28%2C+1994&author=Gemma%2C+Peter+B+Jr&pub=USA+TODAY&edition=&startpage=A10&desc=Answer+is+easy%3A++Get+tough "Answer is Easy: Get Tough"], "USA Today, pg A10, Retrieved July 8, 2010[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Parole%20Abolition%20Passes;%20Get%20On%20With%20It&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=1994&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28Parole%20Abolition%20Passes;%20Get%20On%20With%20It%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no "Parole Abolition Passes: Get On With It"], "The Virginian-Pilot, pg. A14. Retrieved July 3, 2010 Notwithstanding a Democratic Party majority, Truth-in-sentencing (TIS) and abolition of parole were ultimately passed in a Special Session of the General Assembly with the House voting 89–7 and the Senate voting 34–4 in favor of the measure. On January 1, 1995, Allen’s central campaign promise became a reality when TIS and abolition of parole went into effect.Ostrom, Brian J., [http://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/187677.pdf "PDF – Truth-in-Sentencing in Virginia"], Report Prepared for the National Institute of Justice, April 5, 2001[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Parole%20Abolition%20Passes%3B%20Get%20On%20With%20It&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=1994&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28Parole%20Abolition%20Passes%3B%20Get%20On%20With%20It%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no "Parole Abolition Passes; Get On With It"], "The Virginian-Pilot., pg. A14, Retrieved July 3, 2010 According to the law, prison sentences increased for offenders without prior convictions for violent crimes by 125 percent, 300 percent for those with a prior felony conviction that originally had a maximum penalty of less than 40 years, and 500 percent for those with a felony conviction of a violent crime that originally had a minimum penalty of more than 40 years. Between 1994 and 1995, statistics show on average that first degree murders with violent records went from serving 15 years to 46 years.Shear, Michael D., [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-217303.html "Passions Still High On Va. Ban Of Parole; Credit for Decline In Crime Disputed"], The Washington Post", p. B04, Retrieved July 7, 2010 In 1993, nearly half of all offenders released from prison were re-arrested for a new crime within 3 years. TIS ensured that inmates serve a minimum of 85 percent of their sentence. As a result of TIS, first degree murderers went from serving 29.3 percent of imposed sentence to 91 percent,.Fogle, Adam, [http://www.palmettoscoop.com/2008/04/07/allen-abolishing-parole-worked-in-virginia-would-work-in-sc/ "Allen: Abolishing parole worked in Virginia, would work in SC"], "The Palmetto Scoop", April 7, 2008 While parole was eliminated for repeat violent offenders convicted after January 1, 1995, parole remained in effect for individuals incarcerated prior to TIS reform resulting in a rapid decline in the parole grant rate from 46 percent in 1991 to 5 percent in 1998. ===Standards of learning=== In June 1995, the Virginia Board of Education adopted Governor Allen’s Commission on Champion Schools recommendation for statewide standardized tests for academic accountability. The Board of Education voted in favor of implementing the Standards of Learning (SOLs) which measures student achievements and ensures accountability for schools in the core subjects of English, mathematics, history, economics, and science.Brenda Lawson [http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/theses/available/etd-12102001-004301/unrestricted/LawsonBrenda.PDF “Chapter 1 Introduction to the Study”], July 12, 2010Joel Himelfarb, [http://www.hoover.org/publications/policy-review/article/7761 “Policy Review”], “Hoover Publications”, July 29, 2010 The commission also recommended the creation of an annual ‘report card’ to grade each public school's performance stating that: “If Virginia’s youngsters can’t make the grade, then neither should their schools”[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=RTDB&p_theme=rtdb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_hidethis=no&p_field_label-0=Author&p_field_label-1=title&p_bool_label-1=AND&p_text_label-1=Making%20the%20Grade&s_dispstring=Making%20the%20Grade%20AND%20headline%28Making%20the%20Grade%29%20AND%20date%28February%2026,_1997%20to%202/26/1997%29&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=February%2026,%201997%20to%202/26/1997%29&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28Making%20the%20Grade%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10& “Making The Grade”], ''Richmond Times Dispatch'', February 26, 1997William Michael Paul, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=RTDB&p_theme=rtdb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_hidethis=no&p_field_label-0=Author&p_field_label-1=title&p_bool_label-1=AND&s_dispstring=champion%20school%20commission%20AND%20date(12/09/1995%20to%2012/9/1995)&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=12/09/1995%20to%2012/9/1995)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(champion%20school%20commission)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no “Champion School Commission Adopts Many Choice Proposals”], “Richmond Times Dispatch”, December 9, 1995 (2)(9). Experts suggested that in order to improve the quality of learning, a school should emphasize academic goals and effective leadership. By using measurement through tests, the state, teachers, and parents can monitor the effectiveness of schools teaching the basic fundamental subjects (1). Allen’s legislation used public data of SOLs test scores along with school attendance and drop-out rates to ensure that unsatisfactory schools are accountable by the threat of state takeover through court action. Initially, Allen succeeded in keeping Virginia’s educational reform independent from federal funding by using a line-item veto in the state’s budget, a power granted to Virginia governors.Ann Bradley, [http://www.edweek.org/login.html?source=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/1996/04/24/31va.h15.html&destination=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/1996/04/24/31va.h15.html&levelId=2100 “Va. Governor Victorious in Rejecting Goals 2000”], Education Week”, July 21, 2010 Allen argued that federal funding would force the Commonwealth to adhere to federal regulation, therefore, restricting the freedom of Virginia to craft its own high academic standards education plan.[http://www.policyarchive.org/handle/10207/bitstreams/9515.pdf “Remarks of Governor George Allen to the Heritage Foundation”], The Heritage Foundation”, December 9, 1998 Despite Allen’s efforts to keep Virginia independent from federal education funds, the Virginia Board of Education applied for federal funds through the program Goals 2000.Spencer S. Hsu [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-722422.html “Prodded by Allen, Va. He was paid approximately $300,000 for his services.[http://www3.roanoke.com/politics/day619.html Chris Flores, ''News & Advance'', June 2002, cited at] ==U.S. Senate (2001-2007)== ===Elections=== ;2000 {{main|United States Senate election in Virginia, 2000}} Allen ran for the U.S. Senate and defeated [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] incumbent U.S. Senator [[Chuck Robb]] 52%-48%. He was the only Republican to unseat a Democratic incumbent that year.{{cite web |url=http://clerk.house.gov/members/electionInfo/2000/2000Stat.htm |title=STATISTICS OF THE PRESIDENTIAL AND CONGRESSIONAL ELECTION OF NOVEMBER 7, 2000 |date=June 21, 2001 |author=[[Jeff Trandahl|Trandahl, John]] |accessdate=October 4, 2006 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060929025603/http://clerk.house.gov/members/electionInfo/2000/2000Stat.htm |archivedate = September 29, 2006}} ;2006 {{main|United States Senate election in Virginia, 2006}} Allen's term in the Senate expired in January 2007. He sought re-election in [[U.S. Senate election, 2006|2006]]. Allen won the Republican nomination on August 11, 2006, and faced two opponents in the general election: the Democratic Party nominee, former Secretary of the Navy [[James H. Webb]],{{cite news|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=RTD/MGArticle/RTD_BasicArticle&c=MGArticle&cid=1137836125082&path=!news&s=1045855934842 |work=Richmond Times-Dispatch |title=Former Robb aides endorse Webb in primary |last=Schapiro |first=Jeff E. |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=October 31, 2006}} and [[Gail Parker]], a retired [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] officer and retired civilian Pentagon budget analyst who ran on the [[Independent Green Party of Virginia|Independent Green Party]] ballot line. Allen ran a campaign that appealed to cultural, hard right-wing conservatives. During the campaign the [[Marshall-Newman Amendment]] was also on the ballot. The pivotal moment in the campaign, and the one that the vast majority of political observers attribute Allen's stunning upset loss to Webb, came on August 11, 2006, at a campaign stop in [[Breaks, Virginia]], near the Kentucky border, where Allen twice used the word "macaca" to refer to the dark-complexioned, S. R. Sidarth, who was filming the event as a "tracker" for the opposing Jim Webb campaign. In what was dubbed as his "Macaca moment”, Allen said: : "This fellow here over here with the yellow shirt, Macaca, or whatever his name is. He's with my opponent... Let's give a welcome to Macaca, here. Welcome to America and the real world of Virginia." Sidarth is of Indian ancestry, but was born and raised in Fairfax County, Virginia. Allen's "Macaca moment" quickly went viral and, virtually overnight, it became the hot topic on all of the network and cable television news shows. Webb won by approximately a third of a percent – 8,805 votes – but it wasn't until November 9, 2006 that Allen finally held a press conference in Alexandria, Virginia announcing he had conceded the race to now Senator Elect, James Webb, and would not seek a recount. ===Tenure=== The bills that Allen introduced or authored in the Senate include:[http://thomas.loc.gov Legislation in Current Congress]. In Tight Virginia Race, Seeking Every Edge, by Jonathan Weisman, New York Times, 20 July 2012Allen, Kaine find common ground at forum, by David Sherfinski-The Washington Times, 28 June 2012 ===Ownership of Barr Labs stock=== It was reported on August 8, 2006, that Allen owned stock in [[Barr Pharmaceuticals]], maker of the [[Levonorgestrel|Plan B]] "[[morning after pill]]". Sidarth]], referring to him as "Macaca."{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9G7gq7GQ71c |title=Allen's Listening Tour |publisher=YouTube |date=August 14, 2006 |accessdate=August 15, 2006 }}]] See also: [[Controversies of the United States Senate election in Virginia, 2006#Allen's Macaca controversy|Controversies of the United States Senate election in Virginia, 2006]], "Allen's ''Macaca'' controversy" On August 11, 2006, at a campaign stop in [[Breaks Interstate Park|Breaks, Virginia]], near the [[Kentucky]] border, Allen twice used the word ''[[Macaca (slur)|macaca]]'' to refer to [[S.R. He then revised his story, saying he meant to call Sidarth "caca" and then claiming that he did not know the meaning of the word.{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/14/AR2006081400589.html |title=Allen Quip Provokes Outrage, Apology |first=Tim |last=Craig |date=August 15, 2006 |work=Washington Post |page=A01 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5QezZMh6m | archivedate = July 27, 2007| deadurl=no}} In 2008, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' speculated that, were it not for this double utterance, Allen would have been a strong candidate for the [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|2008 GOP presidential nomination]].{{cite news|title=The 'What If' of Allen Haunts the GOP Race|author=Tim Craig|work=The Washington Post|date=February 6, 2008|page=B01|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/05/AR2008020503237.html}}{{Citation | last = Feld | first = Lowell | title = George Allen: "Macaca" Was a "Made Up Word" | newspaper=Blue Virginia | year = 2011 | date = January 24 | url = http://www.bluevirginia.us/diary/2922/allen-announcement-brings-early-attack-on-radkte | accessdate = January 25, 2011 | quote = }} ''Macaca'' is a pejorative epithet used by [[francophone]] colonialists in Africa for the native black population. It is derived from the name of the genus comprising [[macaque]] monkeys whose name has also itself been used as a racial slur. Allen's mother was born in North Africa. The macaque's genus name, Macaca, is a latinization of the Bantu (Kongo) ma-kako, meaning "monkey". ===Allegations of Allen's use of racial slurs in college=== On September 24, 2006, [[Salon.com]] Washington correspondent Michael Scherer reported that the magazine had interviewed 19 of his teammates and that "[t]hree former college football teammates of Sen. George Allen say that the Virginia Republican repeatedly used the racial epithet '[[nigger]]' and demonstrated racist attitudes toward blacks during the early 1970s."{{cite news |url=http://salon.com/news/feature/2006/09/24/allen_football/ |title=Teammates: Allen used "N-word" in college |publisher=[[Salon.com]] |date=September 24, 2006 |accessdate=October 29, 2006|first=Michael |last=Scherer}} One of Allen's classmates who made such a claim is [[University of Virginia]] political science professor [[Larry Sabato]]. Sabato later said his information was second hand.{{cite web|url=http://www.readthehook.com/stories/2006/11/02/COVER-Sabato-E.doc.aspx |title=COVER- Life of Larry: How Sabato faces the election | The Hook - Charlottesville's weekly newspaper, news magazine |publisher=Readthehook.com |date=2006-11-02 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} However, seven teammates have stated they do not recall any racist behavior on Allen's part. Four of these have made statements that were released by the Allen campaign.{{cite news |url=http://www.roanoke.com/politics/wb/wb/xp-84366 |title=Allen denies use of racial epithet at UVa |last=Sluss |first=Michael |publisher=Roanoke.com |date=September 26, 2006 }} Allen dismissed the claims as "ludicrously false."{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/15001190/|title=Sen. Allen Denies Using Racial Slur|agency=Associated Press |accessdate=October 29, 2006|date=September 25, 2006|first=Bob|last=Lewis}} ===Mother's religious and ethnic background=== On August 25, 2006, the Jewish periodical ''[[The Forward]]'' reported that in all likelihood, Allen's mother Etty Allen, ''née'' Henrietta Lumbroso, was Jewish.{{cite news |url=http://forward.com/articles/1442/alleged-slur-casts-spotlight-on-senatores-jewis/ |title=Alleged Slur Casts Spotlight On Senator’s (Jewish?) Roots |last=Kessler |first=E.J. |work=The Forward |date=August 25, 2006 |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |publisher=The Jewish Daily Forward}} At a debate on September 18, 2006, [[WUSA-TV]] reporter [[Peggy Fox]] noted to Allen, "It has been reported that your grandfather Felix, whom you were given your middle name for, was Jewish." Fox went on to ask, "Could you please tell us whether your forebearers include Jews, and if so, at which point Jewish identity might have ended?" Allen responded "You know what our first freedom in our country was? Freedom of religion. So I'd like to ask you, why is that relevant, my religion, Jim's religion, or the religious beliefs of anyone out here?"{{cite web|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0609/24/rs.01.html |title=CNN Reliable Sources |last=Kurtz |first=Howard |date=September 24, 2006}} He went on to criticize Fox for making his religious heritage an issue, stating that "one of those values is freedom of religion and not making aspersions about people".{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6123064 |title=NPR |last=Naylor |first=Bryan |date=September 22, 2006}} This incident was then used to prompt speculation that he wanted to conceal his Jewish ancestry. The next day, Allen issued a statement confirming his mother's Jewish ancestry. Allen said his mother feared retribution against her family if her religious and ethnic background became public, and had originally asked Allen to keep that information private.{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/20/AR2006092001965.html |title=Allen's Mother Revealed Jewish Heritage to Him Last Month |work=Washington Post |date=September 21, 2006 |accessdate=November 9, 2006 |last=Shear |first=Michael D |page=A01}} ===Allen speaks about his Jewish heritage=== On August 19, 2010, Allen, the keynote speaker, addressed the [[Jewish Learning Institute]]’s [[National Jewish Retreat]] in [[Reston, Virginia]]. In a late August 2006 visit, Allen asked his mother about her Jewish ancestry. After she revealed her Jewish ancestry, Allen described the discovery of his true roots as “interestingly positive.” In referring to Allen’s mother concealing her Jewish heritage, Allen said that “I’m proud of my family and heritage. And I wanted to learn more about it, which I have...”[http://lubavitch.com/news/article/2029427/Former-Governor-and-Senator-George-Allen-Addresses-National-Jewish-Retreat.html "Former Governor and Senator George Allen Addresses National Jewish Retreat"], Chabad Lubavitch News", August 19, 2010 During World War II, Allen’s Jewish grandfather, Felix Lumbroso, was imprisoned by the Nazis for his resistance efforts in French Tunisia. Allen's middle name, Felix, honors his grandfather.Associated Press, [http://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-08-19-allen19_ST_N.htm"], USA Today", August 19, 2010 Allen went on to add that: “The core principle of freedom of conscience, beliefs and religion was no longer a matter of enlightened philosophy to me; it became deeply personal in my heart-wrenching realization of how fear and persecution so tormented my loving, loyal mother’s life.” Allen’s speech also covered his devoted interests to stop racism and anti Semitism: “A salient lesson I learned is: when injustice or the ugly head of racism, anti-Semitism, or repression arises, leaders must deplore it. Otherwise, people may believe it to be acceptable or condoned...We need to understand that the denial of freedom and opportunity to any person anywhere is an injustice that should be intolerable to freedom-loving people everywhere.” The speech ended with a standing ovation as Allen blew the symbolic shofar, a ram’s horn used for Jewish Holy days.Jason Horowitz, [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/20/AR2010082005487_2.html?sid=ST2009081303022 "George Allen looks to his roots while planting campaign seeds"], "Washington Post", August 21, 2010 ===Views on the Confederate flag=== Allen wore a [[Confederate flag]] pin for his high school senior class photo. In 1993, Allen's first statewide TV campaign ad for governor included a Confederate flag. Greg Stevens, the political consultant who made the 1993 TV ad, confirmed its inclusion. Allen has confirmed that the pin in his high school yearbook was a Confederate flag. Allen, who was observed by classmates at Palos Verdes High School driving his Ford Mustang with the Confederate flag in the front license plate frame, has said "it is possible" that he had a Confederate flag on his car in high school.{{cite news |url=http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=20060508&s=lizza050806 |title=GEORGE ALLEN'S RACE PROBLEM |publisher=The New Republic |date=May 8, 2006}} Some minority groups, especially African-Americans, in Virginia criticized Allen for his policies and his embrace of the Confederate flag. Allen however claimed that the confederate flag is a symbol of southern and state heritage as Virginia was the capital of the Confederacy. Allen also opposed a [[Martin Luther King, Jr. Day|separate state holiday commemorating]] [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/14/AR2006081401114.html |title=George Allen's America |work=Washington Post |date=August 15, 2006 |accessdate=November 9, 2006}} The state holiday in favor of Martin Luther King Jr. was initially attached to Lee-Jackson day, a day honoring noted Confederate Generals [[Robert E. Lee]] and [[Stonewall Jackson]]. In 1995, 1996, and 1997, Allen proclaimed April as Confederate History and Heritage Month and called the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] "a four-year struggle for independence and sovereign rights."{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DEFD7103CF932A25757C0A961958260 |title=Governor Is Criticized For 'Confederacy Month' |work=The New York Times |date=April 11, 1997}} On October 2, 2010, columnist [[Robert McCartney (journalist)|Robert McCartney]] of the ''Washington Post'' reported that Allen supports current Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell's plan to name April 2011 "Civil War in Virginia" month.Rosiland S. Helderman, [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/24/AR2010092406276.html "Seeking racial unity over slavery silence, McDonnell turns 'Confederate History Month' into 'Civil War in Virginia' remembrance"], "Washington Post", September 24, 2010 "Allen in a two-sentence response to my request for comment, said he agreed with McDonnell's 'decision to recognize all aspects of this pivotal and tragic time in our nation's history.' Although he didn't use the word 'slavery,' Allen indirectly welcomed the Union's victory in 1865 as an advance for liberty. 'It is vital that we understand the motivations, lives and deaths of the men and women of every background, race and social status who were part of this important struggle to fulfill the words of the Declaration of Independence, that all men and women should enjoy the freedom and rights given to them by God,' Allen said."Robert McCartney, [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/02/AR2010100203167_pf.html "McCartney: McDonnell was right to scrap Confederate History Month, but will rest of Va. GOP follow his admirable lead?"], "Washington Post", October 2, 2010 While serving in the Senate, Allen played a minor role as a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] officer in the 2003 film ''[[Gods and Generals (film)|Gods and Generals]]'', a movie that included many [[cameo appearance|cameo]]s of politicians such as Senator [[Robert Byrd]] and former Senator [[Phil Gramm]].http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1329758/ His role included singing "[[The Bonnie Blue Flag]]". ===Allen's sister's memoir=== In 2000, Allen's younger sister [[Jennifer Allen Richard]] wrote in her memoir ''Fifth Quarter: The Scrimmage of a Football Coach's Daughter'' ([[Random House]] Publishing, 2000) that Allen sometimes violently attacked his younger siblings and his sister's boyfriend during his childhood.[http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0812992326 Fifth Quarter: The Scrimmage of a Football Coach's Daughter] Contains editorial reviews In May 2006, Richard qualified some of the claims made in the book.{{cite news |url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory?id=1961584&page=3 |title=Campaign Complicates Allen's Ambitions|publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=May 14, 2006 Ron Fournier}} She stated that the book was a "novelization of the past" and written from the perspective of a young girl "surrounded by older brothers and a larger-than-life father." She states that she has a good relationship with her brother and noted that Allen stepped in for their father to walk her down the aisle at her wedding. ==Personal life== Allen married Anne Patrice Rubel in June 1979. They divorced in 1983. In 1986 Allen married Susan Brown. The couple has three children: Tyler, Forrest and Brooke. The Allens are residents of [[Mount Vernon, Virginia|Mount Vernon]], Virginia. Allen is a member of the [[Presbyterian Church]]. He is fond of using [[American football|football]] [[metaphor]]s, a tendency that has been remarked upon by journalists and political commentators.{{cite web |url=http://markschmitt.typepad.com/decembrist/2005/05/a_tough_questio.html |title=A Tough Question for George Allen |work=The Decembrist |date=May 13, 2005 |accessdate=August 15, 2006 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A1422-2005Feb5.html |title=Mixing Politics, Pigskins |work=The Washington Post |date=February 6, 2006 |page=C01 | first=Dana | last=Milbank | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons cat|George Allen (U.S. politician)}} {{sisterlinks|George Allen}} * [http://www.georgeallen.com/ Personal website] *{{CongLinks | congbio = a000121 | rollcall = | votesmart = 22404 | washpo = gIQA45cdKP | ballot = George_Allen | ontheissues = Senate/George_Allen.htm | govtrack = 300004 | opencong = | legistorm = 4/Sen_George_Allen.html | opensecrets = N00009957 | fec = S8VA00214 | c-span = georgeallen | rose = | imdb = 1329758 }} *[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14973254/site/newsweek/ Who Is George Allen, Anyway?], ''[[Newsweek]]'', October 2, 2006 ;Archival Records *[http://wayback.archive-it.org/386/*/http://www.georgeallen.com/ Archived Web Site of George Allen for U.S. Senate, 2006] part of [http://www.archive-it.org/public/collection.html?id=386 Virginia Statewide Election Campaign Websites, 2006] at [http://www.virginiamemory.com/collections/archival_web_collections Virginia Memory] *[http://ead.lib.virginia.edu/cocoon/vivaead/published/lva/vi03041.xml.frame A Guide to the Executive Office Records of Virginia Governor George F.
